instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
edit: Going to add details in tomorrow; was able to locate the schematic/boardview. Stay tuned.

That being said, the CPU gets warm when I plug the charger in, but there's no power. Would this eliminate the shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>? I'm not sure if this is enough to get started (until I track down the schematic), but I'll edit this thread in a bit if I can find the schematic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Of course after posting, I found the schematic. I'll edit my OP tomorrow with more information--sorry for the barebones post.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: The CPU gets warm but there is no power? If the CPU is getting warm and none of the other rails are coming high then I can already tell you this board is fucked.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Hey Duke, yeah the CPU got warm on the very last test I performed; I think the board IS powering on, but when in the top-case, it's not. The unit had no liquid evident, so I didn't check top-case yet, but board showed no signs of life the few times I tried in the case assembly. The CPU got warm only after I plugged the board in after removing from the top-case. I'll be getting some proper diagnostics on it tomorrow morning and will post back. I jumped the gun in posting this thread because I had no schematic, but there was no way to close/delete it immediately; I added what little info I had to help justify the thread, ha! Apologies for that.

Will update soon with exact issue/questions.
